abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs with the
            Implementation Completion Report ratings of a satisfactory
            project outcome, substantial institutional development
            impacts, likely sustainability, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. However, there
            are some concerns about the on-going privatization of
            Bedouin rangelands, which has the potential to be both
            inequitable, and a constraint to sustainable range
            management in a highly spatially, and temporally variable,
            low rainfall environment. The experience of this project
            confirms several familiar lessons: Participatory approaches
            require an initial phase-in period of skills development,
            and community interaction, even more so if involving women
            in a highly traditional society. While independent project
            units aim at immediate implementation benefits in a
            slow-moving bureaucracy, even bearing the burden of
            subsequent costs in terms of sustainability (though possibly
            justified initially in a pilot demonstration), such a pilot
            however, still leaves the longer-term institutional
            questions unanswered, with institutional sustainability
            remaining at the heart of the development process.
            Notwithstanding, addressing shorter-term welfare, and
            poverty is an important precondition, ultimately, for
            addressing longer-term natural resource sustainability.
            Finally, despite the potential of participatory development
            processes at village levels to improve public services, yet,
            coordination difficulties between programs, often limit such
            processes to only one program, which is neither effective,
            nor efficient.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Matruh Resource Management Project
            (MRMP) for Egypt had a satisfactory outcome, with likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impact, and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            Borrower.  Lessons were learned in the areas of overall
            design and participatory approaches and technical or
            institutional items.  A multi-sectoral/multi-disciplinary
            approach in natural resource management and poverty
            alleviation projects is more likely to achieve objectives
            and should be a first step towards decentralization and
            local level institutional integration.  Participatory
            project implementation requires flexible budgeting
            unconstrained by predetermined outputs, relying on
            demand-driven identification of activities, to be fully
            responsive to beneficiary demands, coupled with a change in
            monitoring and evaluation.  Adequate initial training and
            capacity building is a prerequisite to activities requiring
            beneficiary participation.  Rural credit programs require
            mechanisms that adapt to constraints of both the financial
            institutions and the beneficiaries and identify a process to
            bring the two parties into a situation of mutual trust.  The
            failure to address problems of collateral, religious views
            to interest rate payment and need for credit delivery at
            lowest levels will likely lead to failure and eventual
            component cancellation.  Targeting the poorest segments of
            the society can be a challenging process where communities
            have strong traditional structures, and requires time, clear
            monitoring mechanisms. and strong engagement with the tribal
            organization.  Accurate unit cost estimation of
            infrastructure sub-projects is a prerequisite to
            implementation.  Community rangeland management may have a
            higher chance of long-term sustainability through ownership,
            although requiring greater initial time investment.  The
            project control unit as an add-on and temporary structure
            for service provision should be critically evaluated when
            embarking on new development initiatives.  Many of the
            lessons learned have been incorporated into the second MRMP.

18154436.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will implement the
            Government's strategy for natural resource management
            in dryland areas.  The main purpose of the project is to
            break the cycle of natural resource degradation and poverty
            by providing support for improved natural resource
            management approaches and practices, coupled with
            agricultural development.  The project is designed to assist
            the population in making the best use of the limited natural
            resources available.  The project consists of four
            components.  The first component is natural resource
            management which aims to conserve the water, land and
            vegetation in the area. This component focuses on the
            effective utilization of surface water flow, through
            watershed management on about 6000 feddans (2520 ha) and
            water harvesting, and on the management and sustainable use
            of land and vegetative cover by the local population and
            their small livestock.  A second component is adaptive
            research and extension which focuses on dryland farming and
            livestock production systems, range management, sustainable
            agricultural development and training directed to local
            communities.  A third component is rural finance which gives
            special attention to the promotion of on-farm and off-farm
            income-generating activities targeted to small farmers, the
            landless and rural women. Lastly, a project coordination
            unit component, aims at strenghtening community
            participation and the dialogue with existing local institutions.
